posts.name: Murilo Miranda Santos
posts.cooked: Hello! My FRC team has issues with gyro drift. Our robot causes a drift when it rotates. Can someone help? Thanks

posts.name: Pedro Braga
posts.cooked: A good first step is to check your gyro positioning. If it is close to any motors or power wires, the magnetic field may cause interference. Also, what are you using as your gyroscope? Knowing the model may help with troubleshooting.

posts.name: Murilo Miranda Santos
posts.cooked: We are currently using pigeon 2.0, nearing the elevator motors as depicted in the attached screenshot. Do you believe this setup might be causing an issue?

posts.name: Murilo Miranda Santos
posts.cooked: the pigeon is down near the center of the robot

posts.name: Aditya Naravane
posts.cooked: Did you let the robot sit still for 10-20 seconds after booting? Sometimes the gyro will be calibrating and that can cause drift I think.

I would run the calibration outlined in the user manual and check if that resolves the issue. If the drift continues, it might be worthwhile to attempt moving the gyro or contacting Ctr Electronics Support if the problem persists.

posts.name: Pedro Braga
posts.cooked: The Pigeon 2.0 advertises extremely low drift even when stationary. Additionally, once the robot is turned on, there is typically at least one minute during which the Rio and radio are establishing connectivity, resulting in minimal movement.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: The vibration from the fans caused the pigeons to drift even when stationary. During a competition, I assisted a team whose Pigeon 2 constantly drifted despite the bot being still. Testing no motion calibration in Phoenix Tuner showed it ineffective. The fans' vibration in the pi stack prevented proper calibration, leading to consistent drift. Removing the fans resolved the issue, enabling the pigeons to perform normally.
